column1: MRSA is a "staph" germ that does not get better with the type of antibiotics that usually cure staph infections.
A doctor, nurse, other health care provider, or visitors to a hospital may have staph germs on their body that can spread to a patient.
Serious staph infections are more common in people with chronic (long-term) medical problems.
Most of these MRSA infections are on the skin, or less commonly, in the lung.

People who may be at risk are: - Athletes and others who share items such as towels or razors - People who inject illegal drugs - People who had surgery in the past year - Children in day care - Members of the military - People who have gotten tattoos
